I said yes to the adriamycin, because mine is aggressive... But I'm scared about the heart damage and possible leukemia...not doing anything more until my BRCA test comes back...so I'm still mulling it over...hoping I could hear something from somebody who's taken it before. He said its really just a coin toss, and they can't guarantee anything either way....but if I were his daughter, he'd tell me to take the adriamycin...I guess just make the decision you feel you can live with, and let God take care of the rest.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2013 04:15PM Shannah75 wrote: Hi Hla76- I'm 37, 3 kids, and was just diagnosed in June with Stage 2 breast cancer.  I had been telling the doctors and anyone else who would listen for almost a year that something was wrong with my breast, but kept being told it was "nothing to worry about".  I think it is a good thing that your doctor wants to check this out right away... breast cancer is most curable the earlier it is caught, so time is of the essence.  That being said, I have had surgery twice on my "non-cancerous" breast for benign fibroadenomas... one which was huge... but still benign.  I remember distinctly that these lumps were very different than my cancer.  They were more moveable, rubbery feeling, with very distinct borders... the cancer, however, was hard... very hard... and seemed to blend in with the surrounding tissue.  It felt like I was laying on a golf ball!  I would never tell anyone, after the experience I've had, that a lump is not concerning, nor is any nipple discharge "nothing to worry about" unless it leaks out on its own...(I also had blood coming from my nipple when doing my breast exams and was told this repeatedly).  My advice... be proactive about your own body... you know it best.  If something doesn't seem right, have it checked out... most often, it turns out to be some benign condition, and you end up worrying yourself sick.  Do NOT let anyone dismiss you!  Doctors get so caught up in the numbers game, and risk factors, etc. that they become desensitized in the process, sometimes.  Even if an ultrasound or mammogram show nothing concerning... do not let that be the end-all in your search for answers...(my 4.5cm tumor was missed by both).  Listen to your body, and do not stop, until you have exhausted all resources available to you... and if you have a doctor that wants to "save you the MRI"... then get another one!  I am praying for you and all the other ladies (and gentlemen) going through this!  For now, remember that just because something showed up on your mammogram doesn't mean the something is cancer... there are many different breast conditions that can cause lumps... but every lump must be investigated...and cancer must be ruled out... catching cancer early is the best way to cure it.  I'll be praying for negative results for you!
